'''Brandjacking''' is an activity whereby someone acquires or otherwise assumes the online identity of another entity for the purposes of acquiring that person's or business's [[brand equity]]. The term combines the notions of 'branding' and '[[wikt:hijacking|hijacking]]', and has been used since at least 2007 when it appeared in ''[[Business Week]]'' referencing the term used in a publication by the firm [[MarkMonitor]] (MarkMonitor and its PR firm, the Zeno Group, coined the phrase; MarkMonitor registered "BrandJacking Index" as a trademark, but not the term "brandjacking" on its own).<ref>{{cite web | title = 'Brandjacking' on the Web | publisher = Arik Hesseldahl | date = 2007-05-01 | url = http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/may2007/tc20070501_555089.htm | accessdate = 2010-07-12 }}</ref> The tactic is often associated with use of individual and corporate identities on [[social media]] or [[Web 2.0]] sites, as described in Quentin Langley's 2014 book ''Brandjack'',<ref name=Brandjack>{{cite book|last1=Langley|first1=Quentin|title=Brandjack|date=2014|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=Basingstoke|isbn=9781137375353}}<!--|accessdate=16 February 2015--></ref> and may be used alongside more conventional (offline) campaign activities.
While similar to [[cybersquatting]], [[identity theft]] or [[phishing]] in nature and in possible tactics, brandjacking is usually particular to a politician, celebrity or business and more indirect in its nature. A brandjacker may attempt to use the reputation of its target for selfish reasons or seek to damage the reputation of its target for hostile,<ref name=Waddington>{{cite book|last=Waddington|first=Steven|title=Brand Anarchy: Managing corporate reputation|year=2012|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=9781408157220|page=94}} Waddington, quoting Quentin Langley's ''[http://www.brandjacknews.com Brandjack News]'', describes brandjacking as "the ability for an individual to criticise and publicly shame a company ... [placing] the brand in a hostile relationship with the consumer."</ref> malicious or for political or campaigning reasons. These reasons may not be directly financial, but the effects on the original brand-holder may often include financial loss - for example, negative publicity may result in the termination of a celebrity's sponsorship deal, or, for a corporation, potentially lead to lost sales or a reduced share price.
==Brandjacking examples== * [[Coca-Cola]] - in 2013, a commercial, "The Bitter Taste of Sugar", for [[Oxfam]] ([[Oxfam Novib]] Netherlands) parodied a Coca-Cola Zero commercial, drawing attention to its unsustainable business practices.<ref>[http://www.oxfamnovib.nl/De-bittere-nasmaak-van-suiker.html De bittere nasmaak van suiker] Accessed: 7 April 2014.</ref> * [[Starbucks]] - in 2006, a [[YouTube]]-hosted video presented a spoof advert for a Starbucks Frappuccino underlining the contrast between consumption and poverty. * [[Nestle]] - in March 2010, [[Greenpeace]] campaigners used a YouTube video that parodied Nestlé's [[KitKat]] 'Take a Break' advertising, to draw attention to the multinational's use of palm oil from unsustainable operations in [[Indonesia]] and the consequent impact on [[Orangutan]] habitats.<ref>Dunlevy, Gabrielle (18 March 2010), Gory Greenpeace KitKat video goes viral, ''Daily Telegraph'' - http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/gory-greenpeace-kitkat-video-goes-viral/story-e6freuy9-1225842479332</ref> Protesters outside Nestlé's UK head office in [[Croydon]] carried signs with the words 'Give me a break' and 'Killer' printed in the distinctive red and white [[Gill Sans]].<ref name=metro>Nestlé faces KitKat boycott over links to 'palm oil killing orangutans' claim (18 March 2010), ''Metro'' - http://www.metro.co.uk/news/818000-nestle-faces-kitkat-boycott-over-links-to-palm-oil-killing-orangutans-claim</ref> * [[Exxon Mobil]] - in 2008, a [[Twitter]] account (@ExxonMobilCorp) was set up purporting to be the views of an official spokesperson for the oil company, only for it later to be exposed as fake.<ref>Fowler, Tom (2008), Exxon Mobil says it's not behind 'its' Twitter account, ''Houston Chronicle'' - http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/chronicle/5920513.html</ref> * Also on Twitter, @BPglobalPR is not an official voice for [[BP]], but a satirical account that has grown in popularity during the 2010 [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]], attracting more followers than the official BP Twitter account.<ref>BP’s Global PR vs. BPGlobalPR (2010) ''Newsweek'' - http://www.newsweek.com/2010/06/04/bp-s-global-pr-vs-bpglobalpr.html</ref> * Politicians - fake [[Facebook]] pages were created for US President [[Barack Obama]]<ref>Tapper, Jake (2008), Barack Obama's Fake Facebook Page (Courtesy of the RNC), ABC News - http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2008/07/barack-obamas-f.html</ref> and US Republican governor [[Sarah Palin]]<ref>Sarah Palin's Facebook Alter-Ego Gets Found Out (29 August 2009) ''Wall Street Journal'' - https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2009/08/13/sarah-palins-facebook-alter-ego-gets-found-out/</ref> (among other politicians). Major corporations have also been the subject of brandjack-based protests on Facebook. * [[Fake blog]]s - may be considered a form of brandjacking if created by a critic or opponent of the person or brand supposed to be behind the blog. * Affiliate Brand Bidding - This is a tactic used by some affiliate marketers. Some consider such tactics unethical or [[Black hat hacking|Black Hat]]. The method is to bid on keywords related to your site / product, but to do so seemingly as a competitor.<ref>Weiman, Lori (June 23, 2010), Watch Out For These Unsavory Affiliate Tactics, Search Engine Land - http://searchengineland.com/watch-out-for-these-unsavory-affiliate-tactics-44692</ref><ref>{{Citation| last1 = Rosso| first1 = Mark| last2 = Jansen| first2 = Bernard (Jim)| title = Brand Names as Keywords in Sponsored Search Advertising| url = http://aisel.aisnet.org/cais/vol27/iss1/6| journal = Communications of the Association for Information Systems| volume = 27| issue = 1| pages= 81–98| date = August 2010 }}</ref> *Colleges and Universities - In 2008, college guidebook company [[College Prowler]] created hundreds of Facebook groups purporting to consist of actual incoming first-year students of various universities in order to surreptitiously gather their personal data and promote the business.<ref>[http://chronicle.com/article/Company-Created/42157/ Company Created Official-Looking 'Class of 2013' Facebook Groups for Hundreds of Colleges] - [http://chronicle.com Chronicle of Higher Education]</ref> *In June 2011, Greenpeace activists launched a campaign against [[Mattel]]'s use of a packaging supplier, APP, said to be desecrating Indonesian rainforests, using images of Mattel dolls [[Barbie]] and Ken.<ref name=Barbie>{{cite news|last1=Whitcomb|first1=Dan|title="Ken" doll protesters arrested at Mattel headquarters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/07/us-mattel-protest-idUSTRE75667S20110607|accessdate=23 February 2015|work=Reuters|agency=Reuters|date=7 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=Brandchannel>{{cite news|last1=Waltzer|first1=Michael|title=Greenpeace Breaks Up Barbie and Ken to Save the Rainforest|url=http://www.brandchannel.com/home/post/Greenpeace-Mattel-Activism.aspx|accessdate=23 February 2015|work=Brandchannel|date=10 June 2011|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224180744/http://www.brandchannel.com/home/post/Greenpeace-Mattel-Activism.aspx|archivedate=24 February 2015}}</ref> A Greenpeace video showed Ken dumping Barbie ("I don't date girls who are into deforestation"), the group created a mock Twitter feud and a stunt involving Barbie in a pink bulldozer, and unfurled a banner on the wall of Mattel’s Los Angeles headquarters;<ref>Langley (2014), pp.183-185</ref> some 500,000 people sent protest emails to Mattel. In October 2011, Mattel announced a global policy to keep rainforest destruction out of its supply chains.<ref name=Ethical>{{cite news|title=Success. Mattel and Barbie stop toying with the rainforest|url=http://www.ethicalconsumer.org/latestnews/tabid/62/entryid/810/success-mattel-and-barbie-stop-toying-with-the-rainforest.aspx|accessdate=23 February 2015|work=Ethical Consumer|date=17 October 2011}}</ref> ''Brandjack'' author Quentin Langley praised Greenpeace for its integration of online (YouTube, Twitter) and offline (stunts, etc.).<ref>Langley (2014), p.185</ref>
== Brandjacking avoidance == Brandjacking avoidance may include: * Pre-emptive registration of brand names and sub-brands as screen names on social media sites. * Staying vigilant <ref>{{cite web | last = Frederick | first = Felman | title = The Cure for Social Media Brandjacking | publisher = E-Commerce News | date = 2009-05-04 | url = http://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/66969.html?wlc=1268859644 | accessdate = 2010-03-17 }}</ref> * Use of social media and general media monitoring tools to seek evidence of infringement * Legal action against those seen as responsible for the infringement. However, action against the brandjackers and their supporters can actually draw attention to the problem (the [[Streisand effect]]). For example, following Greenpeace's KitKat campaign, Nestlé had the video removed from YouTube, but Greenpeace quickly re-posted it to video-sharing site [[Vimeo.com]] and highlighted the attempted censorship using Twitter and other social media.<ref name=metro /> Attempts by Nestlé to constrain user activity on its Facebook fan page further fanned the controversy.
